musicalLanguage.description: The most famous song from The Wizard of Oz opens with one of music's most recognizable intervals — an octave leap. This beginner arrangement in C major captures the song's hopeful, dreaming quality with simple chord voicings. The melody is tuneful and singable, moving mostly by step after the dramatic opening jump.
musicalLanguage.structure: A section: the octave leap and descent (4 bars), B section: bridge with stepwise melody (4 bars)
keyMoments: Bar 1: The octave leap from C4 to C5 — 'Somewhere, over the rainbow.'
Bars 3-4: The melody settles into stepwise motion — dreaming of a better place.
Bars 7-8: The hopeful return — quiet confidence that dreams come true.
teachingGoals: Octave leap — confident, accurate, and musical
styleTips: The octave leap should feel like a wish — hopeful, not forceful
After the leap, the melody should settle gently like landing on a cloud
Keep the left hand simple and supportive — this is about the melody

measures.teachingNote: C major — THE octave leap. This is the most famous interval in songwriting.
Am — melody cascades down stepwise. Gentle and dreamy.
F major — climbing again, more gently this time.
G major — settling down. The phrase completes its arc.
C major — the bridge. Stepwise motion, building hope.
F major — gentle descent. The dream is peaceful.
G major — one last rise. Hopeful and quiet.
C major — home. Whole note C. Dreams can come true.
